publicationStmt.p: for use by whoever wants it

sourceDesc.p: initially created on Tuesday, 12.03.2014, last updated on 15.09.2015

div.head: The TEI CSL project
div.p: The TEI Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon (TEI CSL) project is the continuation of the Cologne Digital Sanskrit Lexicon (CDSL) project. The CDSL started in the mid 90s and has by now digitised 34 Sanskrit dictionaries and made them available online. These 34 dictionaries are all accessible via individual web applications. The dictionaries are internally stored as XML-files using different kinds of xml-specifications, displaying considerable differences in mark-up, data structures, and internal complexity. The goal of the TEI CSL is to represent all 34 dictionaries in unified TEI-conformant mark-up and make them accessible through a single web application, which displays entries from the different dictionaries consistently and allows simultaneous queries in multiple dictionaries.

In a first phase, we have transformed the following three dictionaries into the TEI format:
monier: Monier Williams Sanskrit-English Dictionary (second edition, 1899), [the old place]
pwg: Boehtlingk & Roth Sanskrit-German Dictionary, [the old place]
aptestud: Apte English Sanskrit Dictionary, [the old place]

div.head: TEI data model - customization done for the Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon
div.p: The mark-up specifications used in the TEI CSL are a restricted subset of the standard TEI model and we tried to find solutions within the standard TEI model whenever possible. However, three types of customization were employed in the project. Especially to preserve information contained in the original mark-up and to account for the structural diversity of the dictionaries.

list.head: Customizations done:
list.item: we included only the modules we needed and excluded the elements we are not making use of (work in progress).
we used the attribute ana in various elements as a container for the elementnames of our source files.

div.head: Conversion of the files: from source XML to TEI
div.p: The conversion of the different original versions of the CDSL XML was defined by a set of XSL Transformations for each dictionary. The main objective of the transformations was to preserve all information contained in the original files, while tranferring the content into a standardized and well-documented format. Thomas Malten and the editors working on the original xml file encoded a lot of linguistic and grammatical information in the specific names of the elements. We tried to transfer these elements into functionally and semantically corresponding TEI elements: However, we decided to document the original element by preserving the element name as a value of ana (in some cases in addition value).
In case of monier we could make use of an existing markup documentation to understand the specifically coded information and transfer it to the TEI standard using XSLT.
Because there is was no such documentation for the other two dictionaries, we simply searched for similar patterns and consulted the printed book to understand what had been encoded.

div.head: The structure of the dictionaries
div.p: Although the represented lexicographic data is highly structured and the hierarchical structure is indicated by typographic means in the original printed editions, all of the three source xml files showed mostly flat structures: This meant that nesting had to be build up during the transformation of the original flat XML into TEI. By building a structural hierarchy for all three dictionaries, we were able to conform to the structure of TEI and the logic of the TEI dictionaries module especially.

div.head: Monier
div.p: The source xml file of the Monier Williams dictionary uses H1 to mark entries for top-level lemma. Subordinate entries (like H2, H3, H4 and variants marked by a A,B,C like H1A, H1B) are not nested but simply follow the H1 they belong to. The next H1 opens a new top level keyword.

The markup documentation for the source xml says: "There are four basic H elements, named H1,H2,H3,H4; these are intended to correspond to the 'four mutually correlated lines of Sanskrit words' described at Page xiv: Section II of the dictionary preface" (See the facsimile for further information).

Example from our monier source file:
000 a 1 a 1
the_first_letter_of_the_alphabet
Page1,1
1
000 a 1 a 1
the_first_short_vowel_inherent_in_consonants.
Page1,1 000001
1.1
110 akAra 3 a--kAra
m. the_letter_or_sound a. 000002 1,1
2

This structure was transformed into the following nested structure:
000 a 1 a
the first letter of the alphabetPage1,1 1 the first short vowel inherent in consonants.Page1,1 000001 1.1
110 akAra 3 a--kAra m. the letter or sound a. 000002 1,1 2
The original names of the elements were adopted as values of ana.

div.head: pwg
div.p:
The source xml showed the following flat structure, with tags like div type="e" used to simply encode the marker a) for the following subordinate information:
aa2Pronominalstamm: a) der 1sten Person, enthalten in aha/m, AvA/m, AvA/ByAm, Ava/yos, asmA/n, asmA/Bis, asma/Byam, asma/t, asmA/kam, asmA/su und im ved. asme/. -- b) der 3ten Person; f. A. Davon folgende Casusformen: aya/m (a wird nach e und o im R2V. nicht elidirt, P. 6, 1, 116. zwei Ausnahmen findet man schon R2V. PRA10TIC2. 2, 19. 21: agne 'yam und vahate 'yam), asmE/, asyE/, asmA/t, asyA/s, asya/, asmi/n, asyA/m, AByA/m, eBi/s, ABi/s, eBya/s, ABya/s, ezA/m, AsA/m, ezu/, Asu/. In den Veden allein erscheinen überdies: Instr.Sg.m.n. enA/, f. ayA/ (beide Formen auch als Adverbia im Gebrauch); der zu einem Adverb erstarrte Ablativ A/t und der Gen. Du. ayo/s. Ueber die Bedeutung und die Betonung dieser Formen s. u. idam. Demselben Stamme begegnen wir ferner in atas, atra, aTa, adya, aDa, anA, aha.
21-0001

This structure was transformed into a nested structure, using sense ana="e" n="a)" to encode the whole section of subordinate information:
a a
Pronominalstamm: a) der 1sten Person, enthalten in aha/m, AvA/m, AvA/ByAm, Ava/yos, asmA/n, asmA/Bis, asma/Byam, asma/t, asmA/kam, asmA/su und im ved. asme/. -- b) der 3ten Person; f. A. Davon folgende Casusformen: aya/m (a wird nach e und o im R2V. nicht elidirt, P. 6, 1, 116. zwei Ausnahmen findet man schon R2V. PRA10TIC2. 2, 19. 21:
agne 'yam und vahate 'yam), asmE/, asyE/, asmA/t, asyA/s, asya/, asmi/n, asyA/m, AByA/m, eBi/s, ABi/s, eBya/s, ABya/s, ezA/m, AsA/m, ezu/, Asu/. In den Veden allein erscheinen Ã¼berdies: Instr.Sg.m.n. enA/, f. ayA/ (beide Formen auch als Adverbia im Gebrauch); der zu einem Adverb erstarrte Ablativ A/t und der Gen. Du. ayo/s. Ueber die Bedeutung und die Betonung dieser Formen s. u. idam. Demselben Stamme begegnen wir ferner in atas, atra, aTa, adya, aDa, anA, aha.21-0001

div.head: aptestud
div.p:
The source xml showed the following flat structure, without an explicit marking of any subordinate keywords:
abandonAbandon,Abandon,v. t.tyaj 1 P, hA 3 P, vi-ut-
-sfj 6 P, ujJ 6 P, apAs 4 P, Ri 1 P,
10, muc 6 P. -ed. a. tyakta, hIna, mukta
&c. 2 pApAtman, Brazwacarita; ‘he was a.
to his fate’ dEvADInaH kftaH, yadBAvi tadBa-
-vatu ityuktvA sa parityaktaH. -ment, s.
tyAgaH, utsargaH; ‘a. of worldly con-
-nections’ saMnyAsaH, viraktif.
2001

This structure was transformed into the following nested structure:
abandon Abandon,
v. t. tyaj 1 P, hA 3 P, vi-utsfj 6 P, ujJ 6 P, apAs 4 P, Ri 1 P, 10, muc 6 P. 2 pApAtman, Brazwacarita; âhe was a. to his fateâ dEvADInaH kftaH, yadBAvi tadBavatu ityuktvA sa parityaktaH.
-ed.abandon-ed. a. tyakta, hIna, mukta &c. 2 pApAtman, Brazwacarita; âhe was a. to his fateâ dEvADInaH kftaH, yadBAvi tadBavatu ityuktvA sa parityaktaH.
-ment,abandon-ment, s. tyAgaH, utsargaH; âa. of worldly connectionsâ saMnyAsaH, viraktif. 2001

div.head: Grammatical information
div.p: The monier source file contained a lot of markup dealing with grammatical information spread through the whole entries.

div.head: Source file element lex
div.p: The element 'lex' in the Monier source file is used to mark grammatical information for substantives and indeclinables. For substantives this information is usually just the gender. Sometimes there is additional information. n. act_of_dividing.
TEI version: n. act of dividing. [...]

The element 'lex' can carry a @type attribute with various values. The attribut "type" in the source file was transformed to the TEI attribute value, please see list of possible values in element specification of gram.

div.head: Source file element vlex
div.p: The source element 'vlex' in the Monier source file marks inflectional information about verbs. cl.1 A1.
TEI version: cl.1 A1.

The element 'vlex' can carry a @type attribute with various values. In the TEI file the attribute type was transformed to the TEI attribute value, please see list of valid values in element specification of subc.

div.head: Source file element 'root'
div.p: The source element 'root' in the Monier source file within 'key2' is used to specify the verbal root in prefixed verbs. aMSI-kf
The TEI version makes use of the element m aMSI-kf
The empty element precedes the root in the source file: and_not_from_the_above~~aMS~fictitiously_formed_to_serve_as_root

The TEI version makes use of the element milestone and not from the above
aMS fictitiously formed to serve as root)

div.head: PWG
div.p: Within the source file PWG grammatical information is marked by the element 'gram'.
No differentiation between gender like information and information concerning part-of-speech is made within the source file: m. Vishn2u [...]

The TEI version makes use of the element TEI-element gram
m. Vishn2u [...] >

egXML.body: (3. a + fRin) = anfRin adj. frei von Schulden [...]

div.p: The TEI version makes use of the element TEI-element gram (3. a + fRin) = anfRin adj. frei von Schulden [...]

div.head: Apte
div.p: There is no markup within the aptestud source file dealing with grammatical information.
[Relevant TEI elements in use: gram, gramGrp, subc, milestone]

div.head: Transliteration systems and marking of languages
Keywords in Devanagari
div.p: Within the source files there was no explicit marking of the transliteration system used for the keywords in Devanagari.

Example from the Monier source file:
110 afRin 1 a-fRin

The TEI version defines the transliteration system by use of @xml:lang
110 a 1 a

Same for PWG, example from the PWG source file:
afRin afRin

TEI version:
afRin afRin
[Relevant TEI elements in use: form, orth, hyph]

div.head: Entries with words in Devanagari
div.p: Within entries the transliteration system used was marked by use of the elements "s"
Example from the Monier source file: ~a-kupya~,~a-pUpa
The TEI version defines the transliteration system by use of @xml:lang a-kupya, a-pUpa
Example from the PWG source file: aMSu + mAlA
The TEI version defines the transliteration system by use of @xml:lang aMSu + mAlA

Example from the Aptestud source file, witch is using Harvard Kyoto instead of SLP1: Abase, v. t. aBiBU 1 P, svasTAnAt nipat
[...]
The TEI version defines the transliteration system by use of @xml:lang v. t. aBiBU 1 P, svasTAnAt nipat [...]

div.head: Specific CDSL transliteration system
div.p: Another project specific transliteration system was used within the source files, especially in the context of abbreviations for literature (authors and works)
Example from the Monier source file: Ta1n2d2yaBr.
The TEI version: Ta1n2d2yaBr.
Example from the PWG source file: AIT. BR. 2, 6.
The TEI version: AIT. BR. 2, 6.
[Relevant TEI elements in use: w]

div.head: Marking of languages
div.p:
Example from the Monier source file:
cf.~
Goth.~amsa~~;~~
Gk._1_,_2_;_
Lat.~humerus~,~ansa

The TEI version replaces all the `gk` elements (+ numeric references) with w ana="etym" xml:lang="el" elements (+ Greek words). The `gk` elements were used to mark Greek words appearing in the dictionary. Instead of Greek words, the elements contain numeric references. The mechanism used to go from these numeric references to the corresponding Greek words is described in [the old place] . The TEI File uses the extra file `mwgreek.tei`, created by the conversion pipeline in `mwgreek`. cf. Goth. amsa ; Gk. á½¦Î¼Î¿Ï, á¼ÏÎ¹Î»Î»Î± ; Lat. humerus , ansa.
All other languages were marked using the information that they are simply following the abbreviation for a languague (like '"Lat." enclosed in element "ab").

Example from the Monier source file:
Lat.[...]~humerus~,[...]~ansa
TEI version: Lat. humerus , ansa
[Relevant TEI elements in use: w]

div.head: Marking of special glyphs replacing single characters and abbreviation signs.
div.p: Within the Monier source file many elements can be found, serving as place holders for special characters or abbreviation signs etc.
For example 'srs within 'key2' stands for a hyphen aMSAMSa
To integrate this information into the TEI file and make it more explicit, we made use of g-elements pointing to glyph elements, stored in the encodingDesc of the teiHeader..
Element g within the body of the Monier dictionary: aMSAMSa

Pointing to the teiHeader
sr Â° Â°
sr1 Â° Â°
fcom
Ì
key2_srs * Ì
srs * Ì
key2_srs1 * Ì
srs1 * Ì
shortlong
ÌÌ
shc - ÌÌ
[Relevant TEI elements in use: g, glyph, charDecl]

div.head: Abbreviations in Monier
div.p: In monier three different kinds of abbreviations are used.

div.head: References to literature
div.p:
The element "ls" was used to point to referenced works and authors listed in an external file.
102 agnyADAnaSarkarA 3 agny-ADAna---Sarkar/A
f.
pl.
figuratively _bad_performance_of_the_AAgnya1dheyaagnyADeya S3Br.
6,1
1175.4

The TEI version uses the standard elements for bibliographic information
S3Br.
and links to the list of works and authors.

div.head: Simple abbreviations
div.p: Empty elements were used to point to a list of abbreviations stored in an external file.
The TEI version uses the standard element abbr and preserves the old element's name using type. q.v.

div.head: Expansions added
div.p: The third one deals with abbreviated English and Anglicized Sanskrit in the text. The editors of the source file expanded the abbreviation right behind the closing element 'abE' or added the expansion using the elements 'as0' (singular) asp0 (plural) for "Sanskrit words which appear in the text in the 'indological' font" and the corresponding SLP encoding of the Sanskrit appears in a following "as1" : form_or_shape_of_the_AAgnya1dheyaagnyADeya
div.egXML:
form or shape of the A
Agnya1dheya agnyADeya
div.p: The monier source file documentation adds: If the as1 element contains Sanskrit it includes an additional "s"-element. If it contains non-Sanskrit, the attribute type="ns" was added to the element as1.
[Relevant TEI elements in use: abbr, expan, choice, reg]

div.head: Existing information unused
div.p: The following elements are in the Monier source file, but were not preserved. In all cases the Monier source file pointed to this approach. Most of these elements are leftovers from past conversion processes.
The following comments are cited from the Monier source file documentation.

list.item: c | c1 | c2 | c3: These odd marking conventions were required to permit conversion back to the original form of `MONIER.ALL`. For a user of the XML version of the dictionary, they are probably best omitted (change `_` and `~` to a single space, delete `c`, etc.)
usage|idiom|sense|ellipsis|loan: The following are experimental markings; there is only one instance of each in the current markup of the dictionary.

ccom: Represents a character in MONIER.ALL used to represent certain complex records that needed further attention. Currently, there are only about 100 instances; these elements are probably now vestigial and should be removed.
TWOWORDS: An experimental coding for a headword composed of more than one word. Currently only appears once.
mscverb: Probably should be removed; originally inserted to identify records which were verbs with multiple parts separated by the 'msc' element.

div.head: TEI-Specifications
div.p: This TEI Customization uses the modules core, tei, header, textstructure, dictionaries, transcr, analysis, tagdocs, linking, gaiji.

moduleRef.except: addrLine address analytic biblScope binaryObject citedRange corr del distinct email emph foreign gap gb gloss headItem headLabel l lg measure measureGrp media meeting mentioned num postBox postCode q relatedItem said series soCalled sp speaker stage street teiCorpus textLang time

abstract cRefPattern calendar calendarDesc catDesc catRef category classCode classDecl distributor geoDecl handNote hyphenation keywords listChange listPrefixDef namespace normalization prefixDef punctuation quotation refState refsDecl samplingDecl scriptNote segmentation stdVals styleDefDecl tagUsage taxonomy textClass typeNote
argument byline closer dateline div1 div2 div3 div4 div5 div6 div7 docEdition docImprint epigraph floatingText group imprimatur opener postscript salute signed trailer
case colloc def entryFree etym iType lang lbl mood number oRef oVar pRef pVar per pos pron stress superEntry syll tns usg xr

addSpan am damage damageSpan delSpan ex fw handNotes handShift line listTranspose metamark mod redo restore retrace sourceDoc space subst substJoin supplied surface surfaceGrp surplus transpose undo zone
cl interp interpGrp phr s spanGrp
ab alt altGrp anchor join joinGrp link linkGrp timeline when
char charName charProp localName unicodeName value

addName age birth bloc climate country death district education event faith floruit forename genName geo geogFeat geogName langKnowledge langKnown listEvent listNym listOrg listPerson listPlace listRelation location nameLink nationality nym occupation offset org person personGrp place placeName population region relation residence roleName settlement sex socecStatus state surname terrain trait

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: The attribute xml:lang is used to report in detail the language and/or the transliteration system used in the source.

valItem.desc: Monier and PWG source files: Word given in SLP1
Monier source file: Lemma given in SLP1, making use of some additional characters.

Monier source file documentation: Many of the entries in the dictionary have information about the head word in addition to the sequence of letters. This additional information is encoded into key2 using a few characters that do not appear in key1 and a few XML elements. Please see FixMe
Monier and PWG source files: Word given in a CDSL specific transliteration.
Aptestud source file: Word given in Harvard-Kyoto

Arabic.

unknown
GRA:hebrew

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: The attribute ana is used as a container to preserve the element's name (and further information) used in the source file.

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: This is used to specify the verbal root in prefixed verbs.

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: The attribute ana is used as a container to preserve the element's name (and further information) used in the source file.

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: Represents '=' character which appears in definitions in the form 'word1 = word2'.
Monier source file documentation: Represents '/' character which appears in the text as a separator between alternatives.

Monier source file documentation: Represents ';' when deemed to have a 'sense-separator' function. Occurs almost exclusively within records for verbs. There are other uses of the ';' character within the text, such as within long parenthetical material, which are not marked with the "msc" element..

Monier source file documentation: the Elements "p", "p1", "b", "b1" were used to "mark material appearing within parentheses '()' [and square brackets`'[]' in the text.] [Due to validity restrictions the TEI had to find a different solution: The element "pc" is used to encode the parenthesis itsself, @ana is carrying the name of the source file element and and the attribut unit is added to mark the openening parenthesis and the closing one. See example below.]

Monier source file documentation: the Elements "p", "p1", "b", "b1" were used to "mark material appearing within parentheses '()' [and square brackets`'[]' in the text.] [Due to validity restrictions the TEI had to find a different solution: The element "pc" is used to encode the parenthesis itsself, @ana is carrying the name of the source file element and and the attribut unit is added to mark the openening parenthesis and the closing one. See example below.]

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: The attribute unit is used to identify the punctuation mark in case of parentheses.

Closing round bracket right.
Opening square bracket left.
Closing square bracket right.

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: The attribute ana is used as a container to preserve the element's name (and further information) used in the source file.

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: See. Usually refers to another word in dictionary. Appears in text as the word 'see'.

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: The attribute ana is used as a container to preserve the element's name (and further information) used in the source file.

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: [May appear in addition to span ana="see", see above] The value of this attribute is required to be 'nonhier'. The intention of this markup is to flag those records which serve no purpose in certain hierarchical displays of the dictionary.

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: The attribute ana is used as a container to preserve the element's name (and further information) used in the source file.

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: Mark Sanskrit roots.

Monier source file documentation: [In combination with m ana="root" type="preverb"] Used for prefixed verbs to contain the root and possibly prefixes, when this information is not implicitly given in "key2". This occurs in about 600 records.

Monier source file documentation: Marks non-Sanskrit text that appears at the end of some dictionary entries. [...] presumably indicates that the Sanskrit word is considered to be part of the etymology of the English word.
Monier source file documentation: Rarely used (10 instances) coding of non-Sanskrit text.
Monier source file: [Occurences in source file of works and authors - meaning unclear].
PWG source file: Word given in Greek.
PWG source file: Word given in Russian.
PWG source file: Word given in Arabic.

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: The attribute ana is used as a container to preserve the element's name (and further information) used in the source file.

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: This non-empty element represents the small superscript circle used with abbreviated English in the text. Typically, the letters of the abbreviation are the element contents, and the subsequent text is the un-abbreviated text. [the source file shows no small superscript circle]
Monier source file documentation: Represent various kinds of '&c.' ; some alternate representation, more normally by an XML entity, is required for XML correctness.
Monier source file documentation: Represent various kinds of '&c.' ; some alternate representation, more normally by an XML entity, is required for XML correctness.
Monier source file documentation: Represent various kinds of '&c.' ; some alternate representation, more normally by an XML entity, is required for XML correctness.
Monier source file documentation: Confer. Sometimes refers to another word in dictionary; sometimes, to etymologies. Appears in text as 'c.f.' and is also coded as abbreviation c.f.
Monier source file documentation: quod vide ('which see'). Usually refers to another word in dictionary. Appears in text as 'q.v.' or 'qq.vv.', and is also coded as abbreviation q.v.

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: The attribute unit is used as a container to preserve the element's name (and further information) used in the source file.

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: Some words with the same spelling appear in multiple entries in the dictionary, and are distinguished in the text by a digit. If present, this digit appears as the content of the "hom"-element in the head of a record. This number also sometimes appears within the 'body' section of a record for another word, in order to refer to a particular homonym of the referenced word. Some of these latter homonym numbers are also marked by a "hom"-element, but this marking is incomplete.
Monier source file documentation: Mark Sanskrit roots. The empty element precedes the root. [in case the root-element was not empty, it was converted to w @ana="root"]
Monier source file documentation: Flags the next word 'to' as being part of an infinitive form. Current utility unclear. [element name "to" was preserved in ana
Monier source file documentation: Information for "indoitalic" is missing.
Meaning unclear

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: Mark taxonomic designations for plants and animals. This marking has been done by a process of intellingent guesses. Usually words in a taxonomic designation appear capitlized in the text; so another reason for marking such words was the practical one of eliminating them as Anglicized Sanskrit words.

Monier source file documentation: Mark taxonomic designations for plants and animals. This marking has been done by a process of intellingent guesses. Usually words in a taxonomic designation appear capitlized in the text; so another reason for marking such words was the practical one of eliminating them as Anglicized Sanskrit words.

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: Parent L-number, daughter L-number. Provides links between records for "phw" and "shortlong" constructed records. [points to daughter record]
Monier source file documentation: Parent L-number, daughter L-number. Provides links between records for "phw" and "shortlong" constructed records. [points to parenthetical record]
Monier source file documentation: codes a reference in the text to another page and column of the text.

Monier source file documentation: Frequently in the text, multiple headwords are presented preceding one or more senses which presumably apply to any of the headwords; the last two head words in the sequence will typically be joined by the word 'and' or the word 'or'.

Monier source file documentation: Frequently in the text, multiple headwords are presented preceding one or more senses which presumably apply to any of the headwords; the last two head words in the sequence will typically be joined by the word 'and' or the word 'or'.

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: The attribute ana is used as a container to preserve the element's name (and further information) used in the source file.

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: These elements code Sanskrit words which appear in the text in the 'indological' font; normally such words are also capitalized. [the Anglicized Sanskrit is marked with the"as0" element.]

Monier source file documentation: These elements code Sanskrit words which appear in the text in the 'indological' font; normally such words are also capitalized. [the Anglicized Sanskrit word in plural is marked with the"asp0" element.]

Monier source file documentation: These elements code Sanskrit words which appear in the text in the 'indological' font; normally such words are also capitalized. [the corresponding SLP encoding of the Sanskrit appears in a following "s"-element.]

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: The attribute ana is used as a container to preserve the element's name (and further information) used in the source file.

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: coding of a particular '_' character in MONIER.ALL; meaning unclear but possibly related to record grouping.
Monier source file documentation: coding of a particular '@' character in MONIER.ALL; meaning unclear but possibly related to record grouping.
Aptestud source file: meaning unclear.

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: This attribute is used as a container to preserve the element's name used in the source file.

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: Contains grammatical information for substantives and indeclineables. For substantives, this information is usually just the gender or genders in which the noun or adjective is inflected. Sometimes there is additional information, such as an indication of how the feminine stem is formed or whether the word appears only at the end of compounds. [see list of enhancement using attribute values]
Monier source file documentation:

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: This attribute is used as a container to preserve the values for the attribute type added to element "lex" in the source file.

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: Means that the content of the attribute is inherited by the previous element, with an untyped "lex" for the given head word

Monier source file documentation: Indicates that the inflectional information is spread through the record. first inflectional information appears within an untyped "lex", subsequent inflectional information appears with the "hw" type.
Monier source file documentation: marks inflectional information spread through the record, like "hw", but indicates that the information given, appears to be an alternative
Monier source file documentation: inflectional information is relevant to the head word, when the head word appears at the end of a compound. it is signalled by the presence of the ifc. abbreviation
Monier source file documentation: Marks cases where the inflectional data pertains to the headword, but does not add new information relevant to inflection.
Monier source file documentation: Indicates that the lexical information does not pertain to the headword.
Monier source file documentation: Typically appears in verb records where the feminin form of a participle is given.
Monier source file documentation: Indicates that the inflectional information is for a parenthical head word. It occurs only within the scope of a "phw"-element.
Monier source file documentation: Used for prefixed verbs to contain the root and possibly prefixes.
PWG source file: f [feminine].
PWG source file: m [masculine].
PWG source file: n [neuter].
PWG source file: adj [adjective].

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: This attribute is used as a container to preserve the element's name used in the source file.

valItem.desc: The source files of monier, pwg and aptestud use H1-elements, to encode top level entries

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: This attribute is used as a container to preserve the element's name used in the source file monier. Cites from the markup documentation of the source file are given in desc for each value.

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: Many of the entries in the dictionary have information about the head word in addition to the sequence of letters. This additional information is encoded into key2 using a few characters that do not appear in key1 and a few XML elements.

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: This attribute is used as a container to preserve the element's name used in the source file monier. Cites from the markup documentation of the source file are given in desc for each value.

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: Marks inflectional information about verbs. Typically the contents are conjugational class and 'P' or 'A1'.

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: This attribute is used as a container to preserve the values for the attribute type added to element "vlex" in the source file.

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: marks inflectional information spread through the record, like "hw", but indicates that the information given, appears to be an alternative
Monier source file documentation: Marks cases where the inflectional data pertains to the headword, but does not add new information relevant to inflection.
Monier source file documentation: Indicates that the lexical information does not pertain to the headword.
Monier source file documentation: Typically appears in verb records wher the feminin form of a participle is given.
Monier source file documentation: Used as an empty element to designate the given record as that for a root verb.
Monier source file documentation: Used for prefixed verbs to contain the root and possibly prefixes.

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: This attribute is used as a container to preserve the element's name used in the source file monier. Cites from the markup documentation of the source file are given in desc for each value.

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: This element contains the headword of the record.

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: This attribute is used as a container to preserve the element's name used in the source file. Cite from markup documentation of the source file (only monier): "For non-verbs with multiple senses, these four basic elements are further refined by a suffix 'A' or 'B'. 'A' means that the speficic lexical information (e.g., masculine, feminine, neuter) is the same as that of the preceding 'parent' entry; 'B' means that the specific lexical information differs from that of the 'parent'."

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: speficic lexical information (e.g., masculine, feminine, neuter) is the same as that of the preceding 'parent' entry
Monier source file documentation: specific lexical information differs from that of the 'parent' entry
Monier source file documentation: specific lexical information differs from that of the 'parent' entry
Monier source file documentation: speficic lexical information (e.g., masculine, feminine, neuter) is the same as that of the preceding 'parent' entry
Monier source file documentation: specific lexical information differs from that of the 'parent' entry
Monier source file documentation: specific lexical information differs from that of the 'parent' entry
Monier source file documentation: speficic lexical information (e.g., masculine, feminine, neuter) is the same as that of the preceding 'parent' entry
Monier source file documentation: specific lexical information differs from that of the 'parent' entry
Monier source file documentation: specific lexical information differs from that of the 'parent' entry
Monier source file documentation: speficic lexical information (e.g., masculine, feminine, neuter) is the same as that of the preceding 'parent' entry
specific lexical information differs from that of the 'parent' entry
Monier source file documentation: specific lexical information differs from that of the 'parent' entry
PWG: new subordinate section
PWG: new subordinate section
PWG: FixMe

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: This attribute is used as a container to preserve the element's name used in the source file monier. Cites from the markup documentation of the source file are given in desc for each value.

valItem.desc: FixMe: Cite from printed preface
FixMe: Cite from printed preface
FixMe: Cite from printed preface

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: This attribute ana is used as a container to preserve the element's name used in the source file monier. Cites from the markup documentation of the source file are given in desc for each value.

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: A 3-digit code, assigned in MONIER.ALL [initial version of the file] as a classification of the form of records. These are not particularly reliable in the current version of the dictionary.
Monier source file documentation: This is a vestigial element carried over from MONIER.ALL.

Monier source file documentation: an identifier containing a decimal number. Two attributes were added in connection with the integration of the supplement (Additions and Corrections). These attributes were preserved using the type, see attribute definition below.

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: This attribute type is used as a container to preserve two attribute for the elemet "L" used in the source file monier. Cites from the markup documentation of the source file are given in desc for each value.

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: One of two attribute for the element "L" used in the source file monier. The value of the 'L' of a supplement record prior to supplement integration.

Monier source file documentation: One of two attribute for the element "L" used in the source file monier. The value of the 'L' of the supplement record that specified a revision to a base MW record but which itself is not included in the post-supplement integration monier.xml.

Monier source file documentation: One of two attribute for the element "L" used in the source file monier. The value of the 'L' of the supplement record that specified a revision to a base MW record but which itself is not included in the post-supplement integration monier.xml.

Monier source file documentation: Entry containing a sequencing number in MONIER.ALL; has been superceded by "L"-entry for purposes of record identification, but may have utility related to record grouping.

attDef.desc: Cologne Sanskrit Lexicon: The attribute ana is used as a container to preserve the element's name (and further information) used in the source file.

valItem.desc: Monier source file documentation: Mark material appearing within parentheses '()' in the text.
Monier source file documentation: Mark material appearing within parentheses '()' in the text. "p1" is used in the few instances where text within parentheses appears within parentheses.
Monier source file documentation: These elements mark material appearing within square brackets '[]' in the text.
Monier source file documentation: These elements mark material appearing within square brackets '[]' in the text. "b1" is used in the few instances where bracketed text appears within bracketed text.

Monier source file documentation: Codes an implicitly specified 'parenthetical head word'; a separate record is created with the implicit word as head word, and pointing back to the record with the implicit specification.[In the TEI version is a ref included carrying ana to define if it points to a daughter or parenthical record.]

Monier source file documentation: Some dictionary entries have alternate spellings where a certain vowel can be either short or long. In these few (about 60) cases, two records are coded for each sense. [In the TEI version is a ref included carrying ana to define if it points to a daughter or parenthical record.]
